EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1.0 ABSTRACT

Submission Type:  Risk Management Program (RMP) Submission
Facility Name:  NASA Johnson Space Center White Sands Test Facility

The NASA Johnson Space Center (JSC) White Sands Test Facility (WSTF) is subject to Program 3 requirements of CFR Title 40, Part 68, and Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.  Three process areas at the facility contain regulated toxic substances above the threshold quantities listed in Table 1 in Sec. 68.130.  Worst-Case and Alternative Release scenarios have been modeled for the three processes using TRACE (Toxic Release Analysis of Chemical Emissions; Version 10.1) chemical release modeling software, a commercially available product from SAFER Systems, LLC.  There have been modifications to the number of RMP covered processes and the release scenarios since the last filing.  Most notably the elimination of one of the RMP covered processes previously (Process ID # 1000011031) identified in the 2009 WSTF Risk Management Plan and a renaming of the remaining processes to more accurately describe the WSTF process.  These modifications will be discussed in subsequent sections of the RMP.

All scenarios were modeled using Subpart B input requirements.  There are no regulated flammable substances at WSTF present in quantities above the threshold quantity.


2.0 WSTF DESCRIPTION AND BACKGROUND

WSTF was established in 1962 to support certification of Apollo spacecraft propulsion and power systems and association subsystems for the Manned Space Center, now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center (JSC).  From the late 1970s to 2011, WSTF was heavily involved in the development, qualification and acceptance testing of the Space Shuttle attitude and orbital control bipropellant propulsion systems.  In the late 1990s, WSTF was also requested to perform testing of the Space Shuttle Auxiliary Power Units (APU) that utilized hydrazine as a monopropellant.  Specific propulsion systems include the Orbital Maneu

t out the test areas and into dedicated storage areas; removing large propellant quantities away from personnel located in the test areas, and utilizing smaller transport containers to provide only the quantity of propellant required for propulsion testing

Additional details concerning this new propellant (MMH) storage approach is provided in Section 9.0, Planned Changes to Improve Safety. 

Implementation of this new liquid propellant storage and distribution system is anticipated to be in late 2015 or early 2016.   In accordance with 40 CFR 68.190(b)(5) & (6), NASA will submit to EPA an updated Risk Management Plan within 6 months of this new propellant storage approach, since the current Process Hazard Analysis will need to be revised, and a revised offsite consequence analysis will be required.

As a prelude to the new propellant (MMH) storage configuration, WSTF procured a liquid propellant tanker which was designed to transport (on-site only), receive, offload, and store hypergolic fuels, such as MMH. The LT88 Fuel Tanker, consists of a dual-wheel, tandem axle, frameless chassis assembly, on which is mounted a 2,760 gallon liquid storage tank (2500-gal payload with 10 percent ullage) encapsulated in a protective jacket. It is also equipped with the associated fill and discharge piping and controls. The inner vessel is an American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) lethal service pressure vessel with a certifying U-stamp. The inner vessel is constructed entirely of 304L stainless steel. 

The outer vessel (jacket) completely surrounds and encapsulates the inner vessel. It is designed to be charged with a dry nitrogen blanket or a full vacuum to prevent corrosion of the inner vessel.

The inner surface of the outer jacket is coated with an intumescent coating. This coating is an epoxy paint that is fire retardant and demonstrates insulating properties when exposed to extreme heat or flame. The tanker has been designed to meet the requirements of t

4.0	WSTF FACILITIES REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Several hazardous chemicals are essential in testing propulsion systems at WSTF.  The EPA regulates one of these chemicals that WSTF possesses in an amount over the threshold quantity, the propellant monomethyl hydrazine (MMH).  This propellant is used in several NASA, Department of Defense, and commercial aerospace propulsion subsystems.  As identified in Section 2.0, WSTF Description and Background, WSTF completed the decommissioning of all Shuttle Program assets in 2012.  For 2014 and the foreseeable future there are no hydrazine testing requirements.  With the reduced testing schedule, specifically with hydrazine, WSTF has reduced the hydrazine quantities currently stored in the 300 Area to levels below the RMP threshold quantity and the 300 Area Hydrazine Storage and Distribution System (Process ID # 1000011031 in previous WSTF RMPs) is no longer a RMP covered process.  

The hypergolic propellant MMH is used for engine testing and is contained in storage and run tanks. It is the only hypergolic propellant present at WSTF in quantities which exceed the Risk Management Program rule threshold quantity for the identified regulated substances.  Storage containers (tanks, drums, cylinders, etc) are present in the 300, 400 and 500 Areas and are stored at ambient temperature and pressures up to 60-80 psig. Dump Tanks are used to receive propellant from run tanks not consumed during an engine test or as an emergency dump location as needed.  Propellant in dump tanks is typically transferred back to run tanks or to longer term storage tanks, but can be stored in the dump tanks as well. The Management System Manual (MSM) in the WSTF Safety System Responsibilities and Authorities emphas the concept that safety is the individual and personal responsibility of everyone at WSTF. 

This safety concept is reinforced by WSTF's Star status in the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).  Imbedded within the management system processes, procedures, and instructions are key safety controls to properly contain and maintain the hazardous substances used and stored at WSTF.  The primary controls are engineering controls focused on the safe design, build up, and operation of systems.  Secondary controls, also imbedded within the management system, include administrative controls such as the use of safety, caution and warning devices; training; and personal protective equipment. Local plans are consistent with the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan (WSP 25-0009).  Typically, the local area emergency response plans address incidental releases (minor spills) in that area. *  WSI PROP-0044, Propulsion Test Area Spill Plan

Attachment I, Emergency Public Information of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan provides for effective collection, control, and dissemination of emergency public information and for the minimization of confusion, misinformation, and rumors during times of emergency.

WSTF is prepared to carry out initial emergency response and short-term actions on an independent basis. Should on-site resources prove to be inadequate during an emergency, requests for assistance from other local jurisdictions and other agencies may be made in accordance with existing or emergency negotiated mutual aid agreements. WSTF will coordinate help requested from off-site with outside agencies to fully establish a comprehensive plan to address hazards at WSTF. Such assistance may take the form of equipment, supplies, personnel, or other available capabilities. This coordination effort differs from those emergencies handled on a daily ba

ss Plan provides a plan for disseminating timely warnings to the WSTF community and its employees, including the ADF-SW and WSC (TDRSS) stations, and other jurisdictions who could be affected by an impending hazardous situation. For hazardous chemical spills, a siren is utilized to notify employees of a chemical release requiring evacuation to a designated assembly area.  WSTF also has a ring-down phone system for communication between test areas and the Fire Department.  
 
Attachment C, Shelter and Mass Care, and Accountability of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan defines the areas at WSTF that will be used for the shelter and care of personnel in the event of short-duration emergencies and establishes employee accountability expectations and procedures.

Attachment E, Evacuation of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan provides for the orderly and coordinated evacuation of all or any part of, WSTF if it is determined that such action is the most effective means available for protecting employees from the effects of a disaster or hazardous  material/waste release.

Attachment T, Training of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan provides planning for a comprehensive training program in emergency management for all departments and personnel who support the emergency services at WSTF.

All employees who work on-Site have the potential of being exposed to hazardous materials (such as the RMP regulated chemical, MMH), and therefore must annually take WSTF-OHS-HAZCOMCBT, WSTF Hazard Communication and Emergency Response. chment P, Hazard Mitigation of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan describes hazard mitigation planning and implementation measures to accomplish the long-term prevention or reduction of the adverse impact of natural and other hazards at WSTF.

WSTF emergency plans are updated as necessary based upon deficiencies identified by drills and exercises, changes in local management structure, and technological changes. Exercises of the Emergency Response Program are performed annually.

WSTF has an Emergency Preparedness Planning Board which is appointed by the NASA WSTF Manager with responsibility for maintenance and review of the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan, the goal is to ensure that WSTF emergency preparedness is in a continual state of readiness.  Additional responsibilities (not an exhaustive list) are 1) to ensure WSTF local area emergency response plans and procedures are consistent with the WSTF Emergency Preparedness Plan; and 2) develop, plan, and conduct emergency exercises to effectively challenge and improve individual and collective response to an emergency at WSTF.

Hot Work Permits - WSTF employees request a Hot Work Permit for hot work operations on or near an RMP covered process per WSI 25-SW-0013, Hot Work Permit for Welding, Cutting, Open Flame or Spark Producing Operations. Contractors - WSTF has a program with procedures to ensure contractor activities are performed in a safe manner. The safety record of contractors is reviewed annually. Offsite or onsite contractors and service vendors performing maintenance, repair, renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process must adhere to the requirements of WSI 25-SW-0005, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

9.3  Improvements for Rupture Disk Installation on 300 Area Dump Tank

The 300 and 400 Area Test Areas are equipped with captured vent systems that permit hypergolic propellant vapors to be safely vented to locations that reduce risk to personnel in the areas.  In each area, the process vents from the RMP covered processes are routed into the captured vent system lines.  

During the review of Pressure Vessel/System Package #3100 it was discovered that the calculated flow capacity through rupture disk (RD-3FU-HC33) and the common vent system does not meet the minimum flow requirements established by NFPA requirements.  Resolution of this situation is being tracked as SIMS ID #20265.  The risk related to this item was covered in PTO-GEN-BSL-HAZA-008-PHA, Process Hazard Analysis for Propulsion Test Areas General Hazards (Including Highly Hazardous Chemicals) and is also being tracked in the open action tracking TPS (webPAPER Record #104789). To mitigate this risk, the system is inspected on a regular basis for leakage, tank liquid levels are monitored, and tank pressure is kept at a low pressure below 50 psi. The scheduled due date for resolution and correction is January 30, 2015.

9.0   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

9.1  Propellant Storage Relocation to the 500 Area Fuel Storage and Distribution Area

WSTF's RMP covered processes are currently located within the 300 Area and 400 Area propulsion test areas and the 500 Area Fuel Storage and Distribution Area.  Contained within the 300 and 400 Areas, are the propulsion test stands, propellant storage and distributions systems (WSTF's RMP covered processes), block houses, and offices for employees supporting propulsion operations.  In 2015, the propellant storage and distributions systems will be removed from the 300 Area and 400 Area and relocated to the 500 Area Fuel Storage and Distribution Area.  This relocation will enable a change in WSTF's testing philosophy, which includes moving large quantities of propellant out the test areas and into dedicated storage areas; removing large propellant quantities away from personnel located in the test areas, and utilizing smaller transport containers to provide only the quantity of propellant required for propulsion testing.

The planned propellant relocation project is in progress to design, fabricate and install a storage

system in the 500 Fuel Storage Area to store bulk quantities of propellants.  The system is being designed to store up to 13,200 gallons (96,808 lbs) of MMH in four tanks each with a 3,300 gallons (24,202 lbs) capacity utilizing lethal service ASME vessels.  The system will be operated at up to 50 psig and at ambient temperature. The capability to store propellant and transfer propellant into and out of mobile transport vessels is provided by this system.  The system has been designed to minimize the number of leak points and utilizes components that have a good history of use. 

The Critical Design Review for this system has been completed and fabrication is scheduled to begin in the summer of 2014. Implementation of this new liquid propellant storage and distribution system is anticipated to be in late 2015 or early 2016.  In accordance with 40 CFR 68.190(b)(5) & (6), NASA will submit to EPA an updated Risk Management Plan within 6 months of this new propellant storage approach, since the current Process Hazard Analysis will need to be revised, and a revised offsite consequence analysis will be required.

9.2  Improvements for Water Deluge System for Propellant Storage Tanks

Remotely actuated water deluge systems are installed throughout the test areas to protect storage vessels and equipment in the case of fire.  The majority of locations that house permanent storage tanks of hypergolic propellants are provided with water deluge systems.  These water deluge systems are systematically tested per WJI PROP-300-0027, 300 Area Firex System Check Out Procedure and WJI PROP-400-0007, 400 Area Firex System Check Out Procedure.    

For the storage locations that do not have a water deluge system, the on-site Fire Department can quickly respond to any fires. Routine inspections of the storage areas and test areas are performed during off-hours by Security and Fire Department personnel.

Modeling results identified that the 400 Test Area Bi-Propellant Rocket Engine Testing covered process posed the greatest risk of the three RMP covered processes and is the covered process that will be reported.  

The 400 Area MMH Ready Storage Unit (RSU) is the largest storage tank in the 400 Test Area Bi-Propellant Rocket Engine Testing covered process.  It has a total storage volume of 6,220 gallons of MMH.

The Maximum Intended Inventory for this tank is less than the above described volume to allow for ullage and is controlled by WSTF operating procedures. However, the Worst-Case Release Scenario postulates a catastrophic release from the tank when it is 100% full to establish the catastrophic release consequences that could occur if the tank was inadvertently operating beyond the Maximum Intended Inventory limit, which is identified in PTO-GEN-BSL-HAZA-008-PHA, Process Hazard Analysis for Propulsion Test Areas General Hazards (Including Highly Hazardous Chemicals).

The Worst-Case Release scenario is a liquid release of 100% MMH, which is identified as a toxic liquid.   The postulated release resulted in 6,220 gallons (45,617.48 lbs) of MMH being instantaneously released from the RSU at ground level into a 1,721.30 ft2 concrete diked area. The total containment volume of the diked area was 860.65 ft3.  Upon release of the MMH into the concrete diked area, there was subsequent vaporization of MMH into the air.

Meteorological conditions used for the Worst-Case Release scenario were those specified by 40 CFR Part 68.22.  The ambient and in-vessel fluid temperature used was 108 °F and a 30% humidity with a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec was used in the model.  An atmospheric stability class of F (very stable) was used.  The topography was identified as rural for WSTF.  EPA identifies that a rural terrain is one which is generally flat and unobstructed in the immediate area.

5.0 WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Toxic plume dispersion modeling for WSTF's three identified regulated processes was performed for a Worst-Case Release Scenario and an Alternative Release Scenario using the software program TRACE (Toxic Release Analysis of Chemical Emissions). 

TRACE 10.1 was used because it can simulate toxic chemical releases using a set of sophisticated algorithms for modeling tank failures, pipe leaks, physical phenomena at the release source, dense gas modeling and Gaussian dispersion. Released in December 2012, TRACE 10.1 features new modeling enhancements which include a new pool evaporation algorithm.  This new algorithm is used to represent a pool shrinking phase based on a constant radius as opposed to a constant height.  Additionally, the number of data points for the pool evaporation calculations were increased, which has the effect of smoothing the evaporation rate profiles and accommodating the dynamics more accurately.

5.1  Worst-Case Release Scenario

All three RMP covered processes were modeled to determine which presented the greatest risk of exposure to public or environmental receptors.  It should be noted that of all the Worst-Case Release scenarios analyzed for the 2014 WSTF Risk Management Plan, none of the toxic endpoint dist

ncy Preparedness Plan (EPP; WSP 25-0009) is the basis for the WSTF emergency response program.  This Plan provides direction to mitigate the effects of hazards, preserving life and minimizing damage to WSTF operations and infrastructure.  This Plan directs response during emergencies, and establishes a recovery system in order to return the facility to normal operations after a major incident, such as a natural disaster or a technological accident.

The Plan, which is maintained at WSTF, establishes an Emergency Preparedness Coordinator, who is responsible for direction and control of emergency response elements at WSTF.  The Plan establishes an Executive Group, top-level managers who are responsible for consultation of site issues and allocation of resources to contend with an emergency beyond those inherently provided to an Incident Commander.

The Emergency Services Section, which includes the WSTF Fire Department, provides the resources to deal with emergency situations related to firefighters, emergency medical response, hazardous materials response, and confined space rescue response.  The WSTF Fire Department is responsible for the training and equipment of the team.  The WSTF Fire Department coverage is provided full-time, 24-hours a day.  

WSTF has developed plans and procedures to protect life and property from the effects of hazardous events. In the EPP there is a Hazard/Threat Identification Analysis table that lists the possible hazards and the likelihood of occurrence. The priority for the Plan follows the likelihood of a hazard occurrence. This policy is based upon the concept that emergency functions for various organizations involved in emergency management will generally parallel normal day-to-day functions. Activities that do not contribute directly to resolving the emergency may be postponed or redirected for the duration of any emergency, making labor, materials, and equipment available for emergency use.

Once the MMH was released from the tank, it formed a pool within the concrete diked area.  From the model output, the maximum evaporation rate from the pool was 8.8 lbs/min with a total pool evaporation time of 5,306.8 minutes.  The TRACE™ model results indicate a maximum MMH toxic endpoint distance of 7,132.6 ft or 1.35 miles.

Due to the large buffer zone surrounding WSTF, there are no public or environmental receptors within a 1.35 mile radius from the point of release to the toxic endpoint distance.  

Administrative controls and mitigation measures used for the 400 Test Area Bi-Propellant Rocket Engine Testing covered process to prevent and minimize the effects of a release include the following:

*  Administrative controls include preparation of a Process Hazard Analysis, training of employees, and step-by-step work instructions.  Included in the training are protocols for reporting and responding to emergency situations.

involves the reporting of significant accidental releases of RMP regulated substances from an RMP covered process in the five years prior to the submission of an initial or updated Risk Management Plan.  The Five-Year Accident History covers only certain releases:

*  The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.
*  The release must have caused at least one of the following:
     * On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR 68.42(a)); or
     * Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (40 CFR 68.42(a)).

EPA identifies in EPA 555-B-04-001, General Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention that if there has been a release of a regulated substance from a process where the regulated substance is held below its threshold quantity, then a facility does need to report that release even if the release caused one of the listed impacts.
